Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I glanced at my phone, the meeting reminder flashing insistently. As a colleague, I was expected to join our weekly team catch-up, contribute ideas, and show I was engaged. Even though the meeting would be recorded, I knew my absence would be noticed, and I didn’t want to seem disengaged. But here I was, standing at the polling station, ballot envelope in hand, as the poll worker politely explained that my signature had smudged. “Could you please re-sign this? It’s just to make sure your vote counts,” she said. I knew the rules—voters were supposed to follow every instruction to ensure their ballot wasn’t rejected. My mind raced. If I stayed to fix the envelope, I’d miss the meeting and risk disappointing my team. If I rushed back to my car to join the call, I might not get another chance to fix my ballot. The pressure from both sides pressed in on me, and I felt torn, caught between my responsibility as a colleague and my duty as a voter.
